channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Singapore Home Sales Drop to Five-Month Low on Tariff Fears
item.description: Singapore’s new private home sales fell to a five-month low in May, as global tariff tensions weighed on demand in the trade-dependent city-state.
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Ng

item.title: Stocks Edge Up, Oil Gains on Israel-Iran Conflict: Markets Wrap
item.description: Investors in Asia struck a cautious tone on Monday, as an escalating conflict between Israel and Iran pushed oil prices higher and raised wider questions about the long-run impact.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Thomas

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescuers search through the rubble at the site of an overnight Iranian missile strike in Bat Yam on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Oil Extends Gain as Israel-Iran Conflict Stokes Supply Concerns
item.description: Oil rose after Israel and Iran continued attacks on each other over the weekend, with the market bracing for an escalation that could disrupt supply from a region that produces around a third of the world’s crude.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Rob Verdonck

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes nearby in the Shahran in Tehran on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Victoria’s Secret Pressured by Another Investor Urging Changes
item.description: Victoria’s Secret & Co. is being targeted by another activist investor seeking a shake-up of the business, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Crystal Tse, Lily Meier

item.title: Economists Predict Germany Will Return to Growth This Year
item.description: Germany’s economy will return to growth in 2025 after two years of contraction, according to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg who are a little more upbeat on the country’s near-term prospects than other forecasters.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: SNB Is Set to Cut to Zero But Shirk From Negative Rate for Now
item.description: The Swiss National Bank will probably lower its interest rate to zero this week and stay there for some time, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Trump, Macron and Other G-7 Leaders Arrive in Canada: What to Expect
item.description: Donald Trump, Emmanuel Macron and other world leaders have arrived in Canada for the Group of Seven summit. As Bloomberg's David Gura reports, rising tensions in the Middle East and geopolitics are likely to dominate discussions. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Adnoc Makes $19 Billion Takeover Bid for Australia’s Santos
item.description: Abu Dhabi National Oil Co. made an $18.7 billion offer for Australian fossil fuel producer Santos Ltd., the latest move by the Middle Eastern company to expand production of liquefied natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck, Stephen Stapczynski

media:content.media:description: A Santos Ltd. pilot well operates on a farm property in Narrabri, Australia, on Thursday, May 25, 2017. A decade after the shale revolution transformed the U.S. energy landscape, Australia — poised to overtake Qatar as the world’s biggest exporter of liquefied natural gas — is experiencing its own quandary over natural gas.

item.title: Wedbush Said to Acquire Stake in Polish Investment Bank Trigon
item.description: Wedbush Financial Services is taking a significant minority stake in Polish investment bank Trigon, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Liana Baker

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers on the skyline in Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Polish inflation fell to the central bank’s target for the first time in three years in March even as policymakers are expected to keep interest rates steady due to concerns over resurgent price growth later in 2024. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: President Trump Arrives in Canada for G-7 Summit
item.description: US President Donald Trump arrived in Canada on Sunday for the Group of Seven leaders’ summit. (Source: Other)

item.title: Israel-Iran Attacks Extend to Fourth Day With No Deal in Sight
item.description: Open hostilities between Israel and Iran entered a fourth day on Monday with no sign of easing, stoking fears of a wider war in the oil-rich region.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

item.title: Oil Options Attract Bulls in Heavy Trade as Mideast Risks Expand
item.description: A fresh wave of bullishness is washing through the oil-options market as the confrontation between Israel and Iran escalates, with activity led by unusually heavy trading of call options at the week’s open.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

item.title: China’s Thermal Power Generation Grows for First Time This Year
item.description: China’s massive fleet of coal and gas power plants logged the first year-on-year gain in electricity generation for 2025 following blistering heat that baked parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh, Kathy Chen

item.title: Retail Sales in China Rise Above Expectations
item.description: Retail sales in China rose 6.4% in May, a much faster expansion than the estimated 4.9%. That figure came alongside a raft of data from the world’s second largest economy, which painted a mixed picture. Jacqueline Rong, BNP Paribas Chief China Economist, breaks down the numbers. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Cuts Steel Output as Beijing’s Curbs Start to Take Effect
item.description: China churned out a lot less steel in May compared to the previous year as mills responded to the government’s pledge to cut production.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

item.title: Low Inflation Seen Helping Indian Rupee Weather Middle East Storm
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: ASX Shares Tumble as ASIC Starts Probe Over Serious Failures
item.description: ASX Ltd. shares tumbled after the financial regulator started a wide-ranging probe following “repeated and serious” failures in governance and risk management practice at the stock exchange operator.
item.dc:creator: Adam Haigh

item.title: Gold Edges Toward Record High as Mideast War Drives Haven Bids
item.description: Gold rose toward a record high as an escalating conflict between Israel and Iran drove investors toward haven assets.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated.

item.title: Indonesia Bourse Mulls Extending Trading Window by One Hour
item.description: Indonesia’s stock exchange will consider extending trading hours, in its latest effort to draw foreign investors to Southeast Asia’s biggest economy after heavy selloffs earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani, Norman Harsono

item.title: Japan’s Bond Chaos Heralds More Volatility Across Global Markets
item.description: Japan’s once-slumbering bond market has roared back to life with a burst of volatility that is echoing around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson, Masaki Kondo

item.title: Trump Hopeful for Deal on Iran-Israel Conflict
item.description: President Trump spoke to reporters as he left for the G7 summit in Canada saying "I think there's a good chance there will be a deal." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Iranian Regime at "Existential Moment of Truth": Ambassador
item.description: Ambassador David Hale served as a Special Envoy for Middle East Peace, was former US Under Secretary of State and the former US Ambassador to Lebanon and Jordan. He gives his outlook for the Middle East region with anchors Haidi Stroud-Watts and Shery Ahn in "The Asia Trade" . (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: UK Lawmakers Take Swing at Irresponsible Water Company Leaders
item.description: UK lawmakers called for more responsible ownership of the country’s water sector, after decades during which critical infrastructure was run for the benefit of private equity investors.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

item.title: London Home Prices Cut to Lure Tax-Hit Buyers, Rightmove Says
item.description: London home sellers slashed almost £7,000 ($9,481.5) off their asking prices in June to attract buyers facing higher taxes and greater choice, according to real estate agents.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Malaysia’s Oil Giant Petronas Looks Abroad to Help Cut Production Costs
item.description: Petroliam Nasional Bhd., Malaysia’s state-owned oil and gas company, is looking to expand output from more affordable assets abroad in an effort to cut production costs and rein in declining profits.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: Petronas' operations in Turkmenistan. Source: Petroliam Nasional Bhd.

item.title: Yuan May Extend Drop Versus Peers as Beijing Seeks Exports Boost
item.description: China’s desire to boost exports at a time of global trade turmoil means the yuan now looks set to weaken against most major currencies. One possible exception: the dollar.
item.dc:creator: David Finnerty, Iris Ouyang

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. China and the US agreed to temporarily lower tariffs levied against each other's products — the first major de-escalation in the trade row that was touted by US President Donald Trump as a "total reset" of bilateral ties.

item.title: Oil Jumps After Israeli Strikes Target Iranian Energy Assets
item.description: Oil soared after Israeli strikes on Iranian energy assets heightened the risk to Middle East supplies.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck

item.title: Xi Takes Push for Global Sway to Central Asia With Kazakh Visit
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping is heading to Kazakhstan for talks with Central Asian leaders, providing a counterpoint to a Group of Seven summit by visiting a vast region at the nexus of competing interests from Washington to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Nariman Gizitdinov

media:content.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Kazakh counterpart Kassym-Jomart Tokayev.

item.title: Japan's Kato on JGBS, Foreign Investors
item.description: Japan’s Finance Minister said that discussions with market participants is a key factor in making sure that government bonds are bought and sold stably, as the ministry neared a closely watched gathering with investors. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New World Faces Key Test With Bond Interest Payment Due Monday
item.description: New World Development Co., the distressed Hong Kong developer that’s unsettled investors by delaying some debt payments, faces a critical test Monday when interest comes due on a dollar bond.
item.dc:creator: Trista Xinyi Luo, Pearl Liu

media:content.media:description: Prospective buyers look at a model of the Deep Water Pavilia project, developed by New World Development Co., in Hong Kong, China, on Saturday, June. 7, 2025. New World launched a luxury residential project on the south side of Hong Kong Island at a record low price as the embattled developer aims to accelerate property sales amid debt concerns.
